nodes.bodyText: Should we clarify what we mean by "during the upgrade"?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -372,3 +372,42 @@ image:images/ccs/ccs-dont-min-roundtrip-shard-results.svg[]
 final results in the {ccs} response.
 +
 image:images/ccs/ccs-min-roundtrip-client-response.svg[]
+
+[float]
+[[ccs-supported-configurations]]
+==== Supported configurations
+
+<<gateway-nodes-selection, Remote clusters>> shows which versions can talk
+to which other versions but there are at least three nodes involved The
+"coordinating node" receives your search request and sends it to a
+"gateway node" in each cluster. The "gateway nodes" in turn send your search
+request to "data nodes" that have a copy of the shards.
+
+During a <<rolling-upgrades, rolling upgrade>> all three nodes could be running
+a different version of Elasticsearch! This is supported *but* it gets less
+testing than the more common scenarios where the remote cluster is on the same
+version. Everything should work either way, but don't tempt fate, ok?
+
+Here are some examples:
+
+[cols="^,^,^,^"]
+|====
+| Coordinating Node | Gateway Node | Data Node | Supported
+| 7.8.0             | 7.3.0        | 7.3.0     | Yes
+| 7.3.0             | 7.8.0        | 7.8.0     | Yes
+| 7.8.0             | 6.8.10       | 6.8.10    | Yes
+| 6.8.10            | 7.8.0        | 7.8.0     | Yes
+| 7.8.0             | 7.3.0        | 7.8.0     | During the upgrade

nodes.bodyText: How about we remove the "During the upgrade" rows, and add a note below the table about our upgrade guarantees? Less rows in the table will make it easier to view.
nodes.diffHunk:

+"coordinating node" receives your search request and sends it to a
+"gateway node" in each cluster. The "gateway nodes" in turn send your search
+request to "data nodes" that have a copy of the shards.
+
+During a <<rolling-upgrades, rolling upgrade>> all three nodes could be running
+a different version of Elasticsearch! This is supported *but* it gets less
+testing than the more common scenarios where the remote cluster is on the same
+version. Everything should work either way, but don't tempt fate, ok?
+
+Here are some examples:
+
+[cols="^,^,^,^"]

+| 7.8.0             | 7.3.0        | 7.3.0     | Yes
+| 7.3.0             | 7.8.0        | 7.8.0     | Yes
+| 7.8.0             | 6.8.10       | 6.8.10    | Yes
+| 6.8.10            | 7.8.0        | 7.8.0     | Yes
+| 7.8.0             | 7.3.0        | 7.8.0     | During the upgrade

nodes.bodyText: Would it be better to refer to version ranges like we do for the remote cluster compatibility table rather than concrete versions that are likely to be constantly changing?

nodes.bodyText: I wonder if we should rather start with talking about clusters rather than nodes, and mostly leave gateway nodes out to begin with. I think talking about nodes may tempt users to have different versions in the same cluster on purpose to use CCS in some unsupported way. I would start describing the scenario that we supported with three versions, where the middle one is the CCS cluster that may or may not have data. Then I would expand talking about edge cases, meaning rolling upgrades hence different versions within the same cluster, hence gateway nodes and what may or may not happen.

 final results in the {ccs} response.
 +
 image:images/ccs/ccs-min-roundtrip-client-response.svg[]
+
+[float]
+[[ccs-supported-configurations]]
+==== Supported configurations
+
+<<gateway-nodes-selection, Generally>> a gateway node can search remote
+clusters that are one major version ahead or behind the gateway node's version.
+Gateways nodes can also search remote clusters that are being
+<<rolling-upgrades, upgraded>> so long as both the "upgrade from" and
+"upgrade to" version are compatible with the gateway node.
+
